Postscript

Remembering Mr. Shawn

Friends and colleagues recall the years with William Shawn.

By The New Yorker

December 20, 1992
Photograph by Janet Malcolm

The news of William Shawn’s death was followed by a flood of tributes and grateful reminiscences sent to this magazine from around the world. The following is a selection of thoughts about him by various New Yorker writers and artists and editors, who are typical only in that each felt that he or she had enjoyed a special and irreplaceable relationship with the man. Mr. Shawn himself would never have permitted this accolade, and he would have hated even more that many letters, by necessity, had to be left out.

Almost every day at one-thirty, William Shawn had lunch in the Rose Room of the Algonquin: orange juice, coffee with hot milk, Special K, or, once in a blue moon, toasted pound cake. Occasionally, he ate alone; more often, he was with a friend or a writer; and once in a while he asked one of his editors to join him. No matter how early you tried to get there, he was always waiting in a chair in the lobby, and he would jump to his feet, shake your hand, and inquire after your health, even though he had probably passed you in the office only half an hour before. The headwaiter would lead the way to the rosy banquette in the right-hand corner, pull out the table so Shawn could scoot in (he always sat on the left), and hand out the menus. That was the next hurdle: what to order. Did you follow Shawn’s example, and stick to breakfast food, or could you pig out with a salad? And then there was the problem of small talk: what did you say? Actually, you could say almost anything. Shawn was up on music, movies, late-night TV (he was a big fan of “Saturday Night Live”), and, of course, writing. And what he didn’t know he was endlessly curious about.

A sip of coffee, a nibble or two, and then he would push his plate aside, cross the fourth and fifth fingers of his left hand (cross them without using his other hand, that is; try it), and turn to what he cared about most: the magazine. Shawn carried a list inside his breast pocket—a piece of copy paper folded lengthwise and covered with notes in his tiny, feathery handwriting—and sometimes he would pull it out and consult it, crossing off items one by one with a silver mechanical pencil. More often, he referred to the much larger agenda that he carried around inside his head, and would pick up exactly where he had left off at the last lunch, weeks earlier. Much of what he and I talked about had to do with scheduling, a job to which Shawn brought hundreds of calculations and considerations: not only what had been tentatively slated for the upcoming weeks’ issues but book deadlines looming on the horizon, his knowledge of which writer might be blocked or discouraged and could use the boost of seeing something in print, and his uncanny sense of what could keep and what couldn’t. He was almost never satisfied, and was determined that the next issue would be an improvement. Months, even years, later, he would regret that this or that piece hadn’t been better—that there hadn’t been more time or more space. Once, he told me that, after twenty years, he still had second thoughts about “In Cold Blood,” and almost wished he hadn’t published it. But the pieces that had particularly pleased him—and there were hundreds of those—he could recall in exact detail, and his face would light with pleasure just at the thought of them.

On rare occasions, after he had paid the check (he always left an enormous tip) Shawn would have a second cup of coffee and talk about The New Yorker in a way that seemed to erase the decades, so that it was as if “Silent Spring,” say, and “Franny and Zooey” and “Eichmann in Jerusalem” and “Hub Fans Bid Kid Adieu” and “The Fate of the Earth” had all been written and published at almost the same instant; and it was at such moments that you understood that all along he had also been working on another magazine: not just the next week’s issue but a kind of perfect, Platonic New Yorker. Or, rather, on a single, vast omnibus issue, in which everything he had ever published or hoped to publish—from the tiniest newsbreak to the longest multipart chronicle—stood in ideal relationship to everything else, and in which the art sparkled, the poems sang, the fiction made you laugh or weep, the reporting pieces told you things and took you places you had never imagined.

Shawn never—or not that I ever saw—had a third cup of coffee. He folded his napkin, slid off his seat, walked over to the coat-check woman in the lobby and gave her two dollars (even if it was summer, and he had only checked his hat), and went back across the street to work.

—CHARLES MCGRATH

The way William Shawn edited the early Dancing columns is something I shall never forget. I would hand him my copy—he insisted that I bring it to him myself—and he would hand me the Times or something else to occupy me for the dismayingly short time it took him to peruse my pages. After he finished, he would fold his hands and say, “Just let me see if I understand you correctly.” Then he would recite the piece back to me in his own words, adding nothing and changing nothing, and simply by emphasizing a point here or a transition there he would impart a logic and a clarity to my thoughts which I had not given them, and so let me understand what corrections I had to make. He was a marvellous, intuitive editor, with an extraordinary sympathy for the way writers worked. He seemed to know how much farther I could still go in a piece and how not to interfere with the process. I would say that this sympathy, this restraint, was the essence of his editorial gift, and it was the mark of The New Yorker under his editorship.

Shawn’s forbearance was not always saintly; he could turn it into long-sufferingness and use it as a weapon. He always read every word of every issue. Occasionally, after he had passed Dancing on to other editors, he would call me and, in the most gentle yet unmistakably affronted tones, voice an objection. I adored Yiddish slang (“glitz,” “dreck,” “schmooze”); he did not. He disliked obfuscation of any kind. Once, I reviewed a dance film in the form of a lampoon, thinly disguised (I thought) as praise. Shawn killed it, saying, in that infinitely sorrowful way of his, that no one would get the joke and, besides, critical departments were not the place for humorous writing. I loved the review, had split my sides writing it, and was determined to publish it in the next collection of my work. When the time came, I got out the old galleys and was mortified: nothing made sense, and it wasn’t a bit funny. Shawn had prevailed, as he often still does in what I write. I hear the little voice saying “Uh, Miss Croch-uh?” He called me Miss Croch-uh, I called him Mr. Shawn. That was our relationship.

—ARLENE CROCE

Journalists like to think of themselves as tough birds, old pros. It’s a business, this writing game, and when you finish this piece it’s time to go on and knock off the next one. But Shawn, who was as tough as manganese-molybdenum in some ways, knew better. He had somehow perceived that writers are desperately in need of praise for their work—wild for it. The hard creative process, even when it’s only getting things down on paper for a magazine, isn’t just another line of work but also represents the writer’s semi-neurotic need to rearrange the world and set it out in more orderly and appetizing forms. It’s something a child would do, and children can never get enough praise, particularly if it comes in the form and person of an adult who will give them full attention: attention beyond measure. Praise makes them grow and go on, and those who bestow it are remembered vividly, even after they are gone.

—ROGER ANGELL

Mr. Shawn was strange. I used to think that what I liked best about him was what any writer who had his attention might have liked best—the way he bestowed himself, his courtesy, his nurture, his confidence that you could occasionally be persuaded to satisfy not him, precisely, but the writer you wanted to be. But now that he is gone I think that what I really liked best about Mr. Shawn was the way he made you feel that you were the only one who knew exactly how strange he was. Getting to love Mr. Shawn wasn’t hard. He wasn’t simply a genius—he was a genius at your disposal. Getting to know Mr. Shawn was hard. It took time, and it occurred at his discretion, and for me it had to do with small, strange confessions that in the end amounted to a kind of intimacy.

Mr. Shawn had fantasies. He had fantasies of harm. He thought there were writers (and artists and editors) on Forty-third Street—the ones with tenuous appreciation, the ones who didn’t understand the magazine—who were going to run amok with self-interest or self-deception and attack “the magazine,” which was his way of saying himself, with guns or fists or tennis racquets or, worse, phone calls. I thought of those people as our secret. Now I know that many of us shared that secret—only, the lists were different, and some of them no doubt included me.

Mr. Shawn had fantasies of democracy. Once, when I was in a jam, reporting abroad, and needed to get out fast, Mr. Shawn called the State Department to see about putting me on an American military plane that flew daily from a nearby base. He called Washington every day, and never got anywhere, and when I was finally able to talk to him and ask whom, precisely, he had called, he said, “Why, Miss Kramer, it was the Office of Citizens Services.” I said, “Mr. Shawn, did you tell them who you are?” And he said no, of course not, he had simply told the nice woman at Citizens Services that he was “a concerned citizen.” He thought it was a terrible thing that a concerned citizen couldn’t get anywhere with the United States government, while a Mr. Shawn could.

Mr. Shawn never came right out and said that he didn’t like something I had written. He always said that someone who didn’t understand the magazine hadn’t liked it. Once, he told me, slyly, that someone who didn’t understand the magazine thought that my Paris concierge—a Portuguese peasant I was fond of quoting on lofty European problems—was “getting to be a laughingstock.” We laughed about that ourselves, about people not understanding. And then I went home and wondered if maybe my concierge shouldn’t be retired—at least, from print—and then, of course, I retired her. Occasionally, after that, Mr. Shawn would ask me about her, shaking his head, acknowledging my lame excuses about why my concierge had vanished from the magazine, but never, of course, suggesting that I reinstate her. He got what he wanted, and what he wanted was always what was best—for himself, for the magazine, for me.

—JANE KRAMER

At a party at Jack Kahn’s, in 1939 (I think), someone was playing “Star Dust” on the piano, and I said to the man next to me, “That’s my least favorite song in the world,” and Bill Shawn replied, “That’s my least favorite song, too.” Thus began the twin strains of music and what I can only call “benign mendacity” that pervaded our friendship for more than fifty years. (We both knew that “Star Dust” was a good song.) When, in the fall of 1947, Bill Shawn asked me to work at The New Yorker, I graciously replied, “You’re crazy,” and then, having accepted, said I had only one stipulation—that he never ask me to write anything. “O.K.,” he replied, and there followed heaven knows how many anonymous book notes of mine. When, in 1961, he asked me to review movies for fifteen weeks, I cursed and accepted. So much for mendacity. The strain of music was unceasing and glorious—music by a kind of house combo, with Bill Shawn at the piano, his son Wallace on violin, his son Allen on recorder or clarinet, and Whitney Balliett on drums. When his sons grew up and moved away, we were back to his piano solos: his Gershwin and Rodgers made everyone else’s sound tame. Even up to a few months ago, I would call Cecille Shawn late at night, and she would put the phone at her end on top of the piano, so I could listen. It wasn’t very long ago that I told Cecille I could not imagine a world that was not presided over by William Shawn. I still can’t.

—EDITH OLIVER

Considering that the extent and the inventiveness of his editorial accomplishment are probably unmatched, it will surely do no harm to remember his oddities as well: That you could not hope to bow him out of an elevator ahead of you. That on an idyllic Indian-summer day he would arrive at the office in a heavy winter overcoat and a woollen scarf, warding off pneumonia. That at social functions he hovered near the door and vanished through it when you weren’t looking. That he was a compulsive punctuator.

When he sat down to read a story in galleys, it had already been punctuated lovingly by the writer, and that punctuation had been subjected to close scrutiny by whichever editor had sent the story to the copy editor, and by the copy editor, who had marked it for the printer. But this didn’t stay his pencil. He confessed once that he could not read without putting in punctuation where he felt it was needed. He believed that all prose should be punctuated for clarity and logic according to rules that are set forth in Fowler’s “Modern English Usage” and are as applicable to one piece of writing as to another, this to prevent possible misreading. Fiction writers, of course, have other things on their minds—the emotional effect of a pause or an unbroken run of words, the establishing of a recognizable voice, and so on, including their own prejudices, which they will fight to the death for. As I wore out one Artgum eraser after another sparing them from commas, semicolons, and dashes that Shawn believed important, and even necessary, it did occur to me that this could be taken for insubordination. Sooner or later, I would think, it is bound to happen: I will be called into his office and . . . I never was.

—WILLIAM MAXWELL

1986. Pencil on piece of typing paper. Detail from Mr. Shawn’s response to a story that the Fiction Department had sent him (prob. one of several that week). Handwriting magnified 10.5x.

—VERONICA GENG

He was reputedly squeamish, a little shy about gore in any form. He liked his cornflakes well done. When I was in the process of writing a piece about a woman who collected road kills and skinned them out for a university but ate their bodies for her own nourishment and pleasure, his hovering image, to say the least, was never out of mind. He would be Reader No. 1. I had not known of my subject’s diet when I proposed the story to him. Now he would decide whether the piece would appear in the magazine. The pan-fried snakes and the weasels en brochette had to get past him.

I sent him the manuscript expecting it to remain in that state forever. After a while, he called. “Well,” he said, “I liked your story . . .” He broke off for a long pause. Then he said, “No. I didn’t like your story. I could hardly read it. But that woman is closer to the earth than I am. Her work is significant. I’m pleased to publish the piece.”

A year or two later, writing about Alaska, I mentioned the truly dreadful packaged food that I had eaten on a government expedition in the Brooks Range, including things like freeze-dried eggs and cold pink-icinged pop tarts with raspberry filling. I also mentioned that the forest Eskimo of the Kobuk Valley were especially fond of the fat that lies behind a caribou’s eye. I posed this question: “To a palate without bias—the palate of an open-minded Berber, the palate of a travelling Martian—which would be the more acceptable, a pink-icinged pop tart with raspberry filling (cold) or the fat gob behind a caribou’s eye?” The editor of the piece was Robert Bingham, but there was always something known as “the Shawn proof.” In the margin beside that great philosophical question Shawn had written, in his small hand: “The pop tart.”

He understood the disjunct kinship of creative work—every kind of creative work—and time. The most concise summation of it I’ve ever heard was seven words he said just before closing my first Profile and sending it off to press. It was 1965, and I was a new young writer, and he did not entrust new writers to any extent whatever to other editors. He got the new ones started by himself. So there we were—hours at a session—discussing reverse pivots and backdoor plays and the role of the left-handed comma in the architectonics of basketball while The New Yorker hurtled toward its deadlines. I finally had to ask him, “How can you afford to use so much time and go into so many things in such detail when this whole enterprise is yours to keep together?”

He said, “It takes as long as it takes.”

As a part-time writing teacher, I have offered those words to a generation of students. If they are writers, they will never forget them.

—JOHN MCPHEE

During my first conversation with William Shawn, in 1974, he astonished me by extending an invitation to work for The New Yorker. I was twenty-three years old, a bright-green rookie, and far from convinced that I was a writer, much less a writer worthy of Shawn’s nurturing indulgence. There have been few, if any, days since when I have not thought of him, always with gratitude and wonder—often with more complicated emotions—and asked myself what the hell this whole thing has been about.

Several years ago, I dedicated a book to him and wrote an introduction in which I recalled the exhilaration of being young, peripatetic, and in possession of the freedom to explore, as a reporter, whatever it was that aroused my curiosity—a freedom that Shawn had granted me. Carte blanche. It was a freedom, I’m convinced, that Shawn, vicariously, found equally exhilarating. He taught me that it was possible to write well only about subjects that truly engaged one’s passions, and he understood that, as an editor, he had an obligation to subordinate his own passions—that what mattered most was the specific piece of writing on the page.

He had an oracular presence, and virtually every encounter with him felt loaded, full of intrigue and possibility. Often, seated in his office, studying his impassive expression as I babbled away about this or that, I had to restrain the impulse to blurt “Mr. Shawn, I love you.” I did love him and I still do. I loved him, though I never for a moment imagined that in some everyday, familiar sense, we were actually friends.

Occasionally, late on a day when I had submitted a Talk of the Town story, my phone would ring.

“Hello, Mr. Singer.”

“Hello, Mr. Shawn.”

“That’s an ingenious and wonderful piece you wrote.”

“Thank you very much.”

“Thank you for doing it.”

No, please, thank you. Again, though certainly not for the last time, thank you.

—MARK SINGER

This curious, complicated, fascinating man—unlike anyone else I have ever known—often gave the impression of being totally and mysteriously detached from the grit and dross of ordinary human beings. He worked so hard and seemed so durable that many of us fooled ourselves into thinking that he would live forever. Of course, this was nonsense, but nobody wanted to admit it. Beneath the soft voice and the elaborate manners, Shawn was a most passionate fellow, and his greatest passion was words. To Shawn, words meant thought, civilization, decency. Words were the linchpins of a just and orderly society. He approached words with caution and deep respect. Certain words appeared to make him almost physically ill and were instantly stamped out, but when someone handed him words strung together in graceful sentences that touched his mind and heart he experienced the joy that many feel when they hear a Bach sonata. Somehow, by encouraging his writers to feel free, to be bold and truthful, he brought them to the peak of their powers.

I worked with him from 1939 until 1987, often from the initial proposal of an idea (he grasped ideas with the speed of light) through the cherished phone call of acceptance and through galley and page proofs. These sessions were mostly brief and businesslike: a word here, a nuance there, a fact to be further clarified. But there is one evening in the late forties that is indelibly impressed on my mind. I had written a long report on a visit to the Argentina of Juan Perón. The narrative ended with Señor Perón unexpectedly introducing me, as he opened elegant French doors in the Presidential palace in Buenos Aires, to Evita Perón. I wrote that I took her hand and found it “stone cold.” Shawn and I were going over the proof. The time was around 10 P.M. He became agitated. “ ‘Stone cold,’ ” he said, “requires a hyphen.”

I became agitated. “Put a hyphen there and you spoil the ending,” I said. “That hyphen would be ruinous.”

“Perhaps you had better sit outside my office and cool off,” he said. “I’ll go on with my other work.”

I took a seat outside his office. From time to time, he would stick his head out and say, “Have you changed your mind?”

“No hyphen,” I replied. “Absolutely no hyphen.” I was quite worked up over the hyphen.

Sometime around two-thirty in the morning, Shawn said, wearily, “All right. No hyphen. But you are wrong.”

We remained dear friends, hyphen or no hyphen, to the end.

—PHILIP HAMBURGER

When Shawn, then managing editor, hired me, in June, 1942, the day after I graduated from Swarthmore, he explained that I was the first woman to join the staff as a Talk of the Town reporter. When Harold Ross also mentioned this distinction to me, it was in a grumbling voice; later, he adapted nicely. The Second World War was going on by then, of course, and any men hired were likely to be drafted, so the move had been forced on Ross. I had come along at a lucky moment. Shawn made it clear that the development suited him fine. There were perhaps only four or five women regularly in the office in those days. Ross, for example, had always had men secretaries. He explained that women were forever quarrelling among themselves. When I told this to Shawn, he laughed out loud—not something I heard him do often.

I have heard that the transition from calling him Mr. Shawn to calling him Bill was a rather stately process, but this was not my experience. Sometime in 1945, I became Andy, and the editorial notes were signed “Love, Bill.” While I was reporting from Europe after the war ended, and we communicated with our offices by a system called Press Wireless, it caused a small stir when the dispatches from The New Yorker came back signed “Love, Bill.” Shawn’s reputation as a formal person was well known even then. I didn’t think of it as important—just an affectionate gesture from a much older editor. It was some time before I realized that when I met him he was thirty-four years old and that the magazine was only seventeen years old—just begun, really. I’m not sure how he would feel about all the editorials and headlines that used the word “gentle” to describe him. When he was challenged (especially by someone who was not a writer), his voice could be steely and his expression very angry. He was a strong and powerful man, and he never forgot it.

—ANDY LOGAN

Mr. Shawn was seventy-four when I arrived at The New Yorker, and I was twenty-one, but in most of the ways that mattered he was the younger man. The era, the city, and the profession seemed to demand cynicism, but he was uninfected. I started work in the early summer, and one of two Talk-story ideas I first sent him was for a piece on the Jerry Lewis Labor Day telethon, a celebrity event I suppose I wanted to ridicule. He turned that proposal down flat, but encouraged the other one—a story about a completely obscure resident of the Bronx who worked in the welfare office and rose each morning at one to write telegraphic letters to the editors of scores of newspapers advocating everything from growing ivy on skyscrapers in an effort to reduce air pollution to requiring Russian wives for American Presidents in order to decrease the risk of nuclear war. I remember Mr. Shawn’s delight with the subject of that piece: when I first read him some of the man’s letters, he opened his lips in an O and shook his head happily back and forth, as if to say, absolutely without irony, “Wonders never cease.” I saw the same expression hundreds of other times, most reliably when I was telling him about people whose distinction was not careers, not power, but some type of pure and marvellous obsession. There was the young man who spent every day excavating the remains of the city’s first subway tunnel, underneath Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. And the fellow who had built a Hovercraft in the basement of his house so he could circumnavigate Manhattan. No other magazine would ever have printed the stories; they’d have been rejected not because they were controversial but because they weren’t.

The more I got to know him, the more I realized the burdens he carried: deep worry about keeping his staff of writers content and productive; the strain of coping with a decade that politically and culturally and morally was repudiating much of what he believed in. But his nearly physical joy in a good Talk idea—in the Brooklyn dentist who suddenly became Grenada’s Ambassador to the United Nations, in the intricacies of the Aroma Disc System—never faded. Chronicling such subjects was his great pleasure. Almost everything else in his magazine was weightier, and probably accounted for more of his reputation, but I think that for Mr. Shawn a Talk story was the loveliest thing in journalism.

—BILL McKIBBEN

I think it was during my third week at the magazine that I tripped and fell down the worn, uneven old stairs that connected the nineteenth and twentieth floors near Mr. Shawn’s office in our old building. As it happened, I was carrying several open bottles of Coke at the time, and about halfway down the stairs I collided with Mr. Shawn, spilling Coke all over him and somehow getting his fingers entangled in my Coke-sodden hair. It is impossible to convey the full extent of my horror at that moment. The sound of the bottles clattering down the stairs and our collision immediately drew everybody out of the nearby offices, and after a moment of stunned silence many hands came forward to untangle us and set us on our feet. Luckily, no one was hurt. I apologized profusely, and Mr. Shawn was, as always, a model of mandarin courtesy and solicitousness, but from then on, I think, he tended to consider me accident-prone and—did I imagine it?—always seemed to give me an unnecessarily wide berth when we passed in the hall.

A decade later, married and struggling with a difficult pregnancy, I was advised to take to my bed for a while, and ended up staying in bed for two and a half months (not such a bad state for a writer). Mr. Shawn called regularly to inquire about my health during that period. And when I told him that I was returning to work he worried that perhaps the office was not a “safe” place. Did I feel comfortable with the idea of going up and down the stairs, he asked. I assured him I did. Several days later, I returned to my office, a long and rather narrow room, and found it impossible to open the door all the way. It was blocked by the corner of a standard-size twin bed, which filled at least two-thirds of my office. Mr. Shawn had ordered it, so that I could rest properly whenever I needed to, and, I’m sure, avoid physical catastrophe.

Though discreet about his feelings, Mr. Shawn was in fact passionate about creating a “safe” (in another sense of the word) atmosphere for writers, and his love of language and his empathy were so palpable that when he responded to your work he made you, the work—the world—seem tremendously richer.

—LIS HARRIS

Harold Ross had two favorite apothegms: “No monkey-business with the girls in the office” (he was an unreconstructed product of his time) and “Any editor worth a damn has to take a vow of anonymity.” It may be that William Shawn carried anonymity one veil too far, but what appeared to be an endearing eccentricity in the modern workaday world was an invaluable tool in the world of manuscripts. Ross’s dictum had been wrung from him during the war, when the draft carried off every fact editor but Ross himself and Shawn, and he had tried to turn undrafted writers into makeshift editors. The experiment was soon abandoned: the writers in wolf’s clothing enraged their fellows to the point of insurrection by rewriting everything handed to them and imprinting their own style and tone on the copy.

Shawn was nothing like that. He would take a failed text, saw it up into a dozen chunks, excise the vacant musings, straighten out the thinking, fix the grammar, oil the transitions, and put it back together as an acceptable piece of work—all without leaving a trace of his presence. Only the writer ever knew that Shawn had been there, and the writer wasn’t likely to tell. When I started work as an editor, in 1945, Shawn gave me as a manual of instruction a manuscript he had edited, by a writer now long and deservedly forgotten. The thing was a revelation. Every page of the typescript was black with Shawn’s crabbed little corrections and transpositions, and the margins were littered with requests for more facts or better explanations. He had, it became clear, completely rewritten the piece—but always carefully using the lame writer’s own language and constructions. What was astonishing was that by the time the job was done Shawn himself had vanished. There was nobody left but the writer—but now a writer who had a competent piece to offer.

I suppose the same thing could be said of all of us who worked with Shawn. Whatever we were when we came into his orbit, we became something more under his influence. He sharpened our thinking, brought us sternly back from our vacant musings, oiled our transitions, and turned us into professionals of a greater competence than we would ever have achieved on our own.

—GARDNER BOTSFORD

The weekly art meeting was, and remains, one of the fixed points of The New Yorker’s sometimes wayward compass. At two-thirty every Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Shawn and I would meet in his office to consider the week’s harvest of finished drawings, rough sketches, spots, and covers. The expression with which he invariably greeted me might have suggested to an outsider apprehension at the task that lay ahead or, more frivolously, the possibility that his shoes were too tight. But in fact his painfully ceremonious manner was only a way of steering us quickly past the usual small talk to a discussion of the material at hand.

Mr. Shawn was interested in all aspects of the magazine’s art and felt a personal debt to the artists who produced it. He appeared to have read and seen everything, and he would occasionally pause over a drawing to analyze some reference in it to, say, a recent Johnny Carson monologue, the sudden ascent of Arnold Schwarzenegger, or Michael Jackson’s début on MTV. He was aware of most of what was happening around New York. I remember particularly his disappointment in the A.T. & T. building—the public spaces were gloomy and the seats uncomfortable—and his delight in the brazen glitz of the newly opened Trump Tower.

In a letter to me after he left the magazine he referred to these weekly art meetings as a search for work that was “funny and beautiful and true.” By true he meant not just true in its perception of the human condition but true to each artist’s vision. His own tastes were conservative, but he could value and respond to truth in works not congenial to him. He immediately recognized it in, for example, the then unpublished work of Roz Chast; and, though pained, he bowed to it when he agreed to publish the words “dumb bastard” in a caption by George Booth. Mr. Shawn’s ability to see to the core of each artist’s creative self was the heart of his editorial gift.

—LEE LORENZ

He had an expressive, compassionate, anxious, strong-willed face framed by rather large ears. He would check himself in Lois Long’s little round mirror on the wall in my office whenever he came in. His feet and his hands were long and thin, as if made for a taller person. Even in his own living room, against a backdrop of the shelves of books whose writers he had nurtured, he looked uneasy. He would sit at one end of his own sofa, looking guarded, as if he were trapped with strangers in a conveyance moving dangerously fast. His feet, in the perfectly cared-for black oxfords, would be placed nearly side by side, like the foot pedals of his Steinway. His legs would be bent to one side, with a hand resting on or perhaps holding down one of his knees. When someone said something that amused or surprised him (which was often), the hand would spontaneously lift and then settle down again in a Platonic sketch of a thigh slap. He had a great capacity for joy. Laughter was essential to his survival. His fingers were long and slightly spatulate at the tips—a pianist’s hands. When he sat with a board, working on a proof with his silvery propelling pencil, all his stupendous intellect was in his hands. When he was in his shirtsleeves, he would sometimes stand with his thumbs at his belt and his fingers splayed out. It was a gesture from another time and place—a world of watch chains, and even gun belts, perhaps—and thoroughly manly and American.

—KENNEDY FRASER

Shawn was so hard a worker that he had little time for extracurricular activities. There were two I knew of before the war—the one he insisted that The New Yorker call “the Second World War” rather than “World War II”—a bunch of us met periodically in an apartment just off the Bowery to play jazz. Various musicians of different calibre drifted in and out of the performing ranks. It was generally agreed that among the regulars there were only two real pros—Larry Adler on harmonica and Bill Shawn on piano.

Shawn’s other outside interest, his only competitive sport, was what I guess could be called shadow wrestling. He would never precede anybody through a door. While his insistence on going last rarely involved actual physical contact, there would occasionally be a gentle nudge. He retired, as far as I know, undefeated.

—E.J. KAHN, JR.

So much to remember. A transatlantic phone call on the matter of a semicolon. The withdrawal at the last hour of a review in which I had adverted unkindly to someone whom Mr. Shawn, from private sources, knew to be ill. The rationed but all the more valued expression of pleasure at certain pieces or suggestions. The shutters slid down like a noiseless guillotine on some inappropriate reflection or on some name ostracized from regard. It became important not to ask for his support in mundane aspirations.

Mr. Shawn’s exit from the magazine left scars on all who had worked with him. Profound generosities of understanding ceased overnight. Now I find it difficult to imagine that he will no longer, even away from the office that was his monkish fief, glance at what I publish. Having taught himself, he remained a teacher to his fingertips. It is that which makes his legacy a specific pressure. I shall always know that nothing I can turn out is really good enough.

—GEORGE STEINER

The first words Shawn ever said to me, after shaking my hand and asking me to sit down, were “I understand you come from a big family.” I had applied for a writing job, failed to get one, moved to Chicago, worked for Playboy, returned to New York the next year, and tried again. I was told Mr. Shawn would see me on Wednesday afternoon at four o’clock. I got to the building about an hour early and walked back and forth outside, keeping track of the time by the big clock on the pillar at Fifth and Forty-fourth. At three minutes of four, I rode the elevator to the nineteenth floor. Someone took me to Shawn’s office. All I really saw of him was a kind of rosy glow above a blue suit. When he said that about the big family, I knew I was hired. The job was reporter for the Talk of the Town, at two hundred dollars a week. The receptionist for the eighteenth floor led me to an office I could use; it had a view of the Chrysler Building. I stood there looking out the window, my happiness roaring inside like a car in neutral with the accelerator to the floor.

Shawn’s handwriting, and the funny things he said—I almost never talked to him without his saying something funny or strange—and the sound of his thin, reedy voice on the phone. The greatest thrill in the world was to finish a Talk story, take it up to Shawn, come back to my office, kill time for a few minutes; then the phone would ring, and Shawn would say he liked the story. Also, there was the opposite experience: I’d give him a story that I had worked on for weeks, and never hear one word about it or see the manuscript again. The only exception happened once when I wrote a Talk piece about fishing in the Catskills. Shawn called me into his office and told me that it was a good piece. Then he said, “The reason we won’t be using it . . .” and went into a long explanation in which he said that The New Yorker never ran articles about fishing or hunting, because it was “a vegetarian magazine.” He said, “Fishing, in itself, is fine. But then you have the fish, and the fish is hooked . . .” He veiled his eyes, looked away, made a small, helpless gesture with his hand.

—IAN FRAzIER

To this contributor, Mr. Shawn’s unfailing courtesy and rather determined conversational blandness hid a mystery: his extraordinary aesthetic passion, which enabled him to make so many adamant and surprising discriminations. A prodigious consumer of information and culture, he retained what he had absorbed: all the tides that had washed through his eyes and ears had polished his own cultural vocabulary to gnomic minimalism. The word “writing” covered the whole vast business of literature, and “good writing” was the height of his praise and the extent of his commentary. An editor-in-chief, with the ultimate authority of acceptance or rejection, has a certain monolithic, or binary, simplicity, and to a striking degree Shawn declined to compromise the dignity of his power with unnecessary elaboration. Not that he was curt; on the contrary, an infinitely patient expectancy was the mood he conveyed, and it was this expectancy, grandly nondirective, that a contributor longed to satisfy. The tiny difference between your best and your second best would be registered, you were sure, in the ideally pure chambers of Shawn’s personal quiet; it was part of his editorial genius to establish, in a manner akin to that of the classic Freudian psychoanalyst, an air of perfect listening, in which you were encouraged to reveal and reconstruct yourself.

Our dealings were few, but they needed only to be few. A softly spoken sentence while we passed in the hall; a compliment relayed by another editor; a friendly word scratched on a proof—these, like the lightest of touches on the tiller, sufficed to confirm that the vessel was being steered and the right direction maintained. What was right was doubly right, somehow—aesthetics and ethics coincided—in the universe of his gentle implications. His adamancy of taste had been hardened in a buried moral fire, and his New Yorker was a realm from which many types of unseemliness were excluded. But his exclusionary sword had an edge of venturesomeness as well: the magazine’s fiction became more avant-garde and its nonfiction more mandarin under his guidance. This shy man, in his buttoned vest, concealed a mental swashbuckler who constantly kept readers and his writers on their toes. In pursuit of what he called “the real thing” he would go with a writer as far as the writer dared to go, and turned cool only when the writer played it safe, or false. Beneath a reserve that bordered on diffidence, he harbored an intensely creative, uncompromising nature. As fate willed, he placed this nature at the service of other talents, of an entire magazine, week after week. Yet his magic force made every word and comma in some sense his. He seemed to me, when I dared visit that corner office where Mr. Shawn pinkly crouched behind his proof-piled desk, a conjurer who, without moving a muscle, summoned spirits from the deep.

—JOHN UPDIKE

I began reading The New Yorker intermittently when I was in college, in the post-Watergate, post-Vietnam War nineteen-seventies. At the time, I didn’t see much on the American scene that inspired any sense of citizenship or public commitment, and most of my peers seemed lost in some form of ironic detachment or cultic mystification. The New Yorker of that time, with its oxymoronic virtues of lively dignity, active calm, and disinterested engagement, and its almost ridiculously ardent devotion to accuracy and completeness, gave me a kind of hope that I rarely felt. When I finally met, and began working for, William Shawn, I recognized that it was he who had established those virtues and instilled that hope. His own hope, which was really a belief in worldly illumination, built a promontory above the flat landscape of the media-projected world, and I’ve never forgotten the sense of being reached for, and found, by Shawn’s belief that the real world could be seen in words, jokes, and handmade pictures. He was, despite his theatrically elaborated reticence, a Whitmanesque embracer of America’s inexhaustible lists of things and ways of living. (The embrace became, more and more, an international one as the years went by.) He was a blushing, nervous, hesitant, and youthful little man, touching in his faith that empathy and care could prevail, and, always, bravely independent. And I can see him shaking his head at these imprecise and emotional words.

—HAL ESPEN

Although Mr. Shawn was a secret person, he preferred others not to be. He wanted to know everything that was going on, but if the news was either disagreeable or embarrassing he liked it distilled through an intermediary. There was a feeling among the staff that he should be protected from the cruder aspects of life—a feeling that he shared. He was not one to get involved in personal matters, no matter how fascinating, and the legendary shyness and elaborate courtesy were also a protection, enabling The Legend to do with impunity exactly what he wanted. His curiosity was often hidden, but it was irrepressible, and he had an uncanny tendency to appear silently in the doorway just as you were doing an imitation of him getting on an elevator; or when a writer and a checker were in a tackle on the floor, the latter trying to make the point that by curling into a ball the tacklee had less chance of being injured. Or, in the middle of a raunchy story, unfit for his ears, you would suddenly look up and there he’d be. “Am I interrupting?” he’d ask, peering up at you sidewise, deadpan.

Confidence (lacking): On his way out to lunch one day, dressed in his brown porkpie hat, green scarf, black-and-white checked overcoat, white socks, black shoes, and rubbers, and carrying his umbrella, he suddenly turned and asked, “Am I a figure of fun?”

Preventive Medicine: He returned from lunch one day to find a writer waiting for him who had a terrible, noisy cold. Mr. Shawn entered putting up his umbrella.

—MARy D. KIERSTEAD

After I’d worked for The New Yorker for about three years, Mr. Shawn suggested that I might want to look for another job. “You would be a great success somewhere else, I’m sure,” he said near the end of his uncomfortable speech. He was sitting at his big, polished desk. I sat on the famous low couch, in despair. “Why, you could be a star,” Mr. Shawn concluded. This effort at valedictory praise was compromised by his obvious distaste for the notion of any stellar entity except the astronomical. On another occasion, I asked Mr. Shawn if could try writing a nonfiction piece. When I finished my brief, halting proposal, he said, “What you want to write is an article. We don’t publish articles. The Times Magazine publishes articles.” No diminutive ever sounded punier.

“We avoid,” his Lilliputian hand noted in a galley’s margin, with a spidery line leading to “smarts” or “urinal” in the text. We avoided, as I learned little by little, “photo,” “intrigued” for “interested,” “locate” as a synonym for “situate,” “massive” as a description of anything but a physical object, “wig,” for a reason that has remained a mystery to me, “home” for “house,” “gadget,” “feisty,” “workaholic,” “prestigious,” “promptly,” the verb “spat” as the past tense of “spit,” “quality” as an adjective, “tycoon,” and “balding.” And it was said that Mr. Shawn wanted at all costs to avoid mentioning the name of Tom Wolfe, who in 1965 had written an unflattering piece about him and The New Yorker in New York, when it was part of the Herald Tribune. Eventually, some one of us composed a mnemonic to consolidate the Diction Index that Mr. Shawn carried around in his head. I could have sworn I was the one, but Nancy Franklin and John Bennet, two colleagues, have convinced me that they deserve the credit for “Intrigued by the massive smarts of the balding, feisty, prestigious, workaholic tycoon, Tom Wolfe promptly spat on the quality photo above the urinal and tried to locate his gadget.” Someone evidently left the wig at his home.

During the eighteen years I worked for Mr. Shawn, I doubt if we spent more than three hours talking to each other, and yet with hardly any effort at all we managed in those three hours not to get along. Oil and water. Still, however inadvertently, he, more than anyone else, taught me how to be an editor and a writer to the degree that I am either. However grudgingly, I learned. It was impossible not to, really, when, week in and week out, I saw the intelligence and the tenacious logic, the wisdom and the innocence that Mr. Shawn brought to bear on the written language, and the deep curiosity one sensed beneath the man’s formal surface. Not a day goes by that I don’t use some part of Mr. Shawn’s example in my professional conduct, that I don’t remember his vivid character, that I am outside his influence. No one in his right journalistic or literary mind would have wanted to go somewhere else, even to write articles and to be a star.

—DANIEL MENAKER

It was George Trow who brought me to Mr. Shawn. I was young and poor and hungry, and could never pay the rent on time. I did not have a real job, because I could not do anything very well. I wanted to be a writer. I didn’t know how to do that, but when anyone asked me what I did, I would say I was a writer; but that wasn’t true; I couldn’t write at all. A man named Michael O’Donoghue introduced me to George Trow, who must have felt sorry for me, because he began to take me with him to all sorts of places around town and feed me afterward. One night, we were eating dinner in a restaurant that served only Lebanese food, and I said something about a person we knew that made George laugh very hard. And when he had stopped laughing he asked if I would like to meet Mr. Shawn, and I said yes. The three of us met for lunch at the Algonquin. I was hungry and ordered the most expensive thing I could find on the menu, a seafood salad. I don’t remember what George ordered. Mr. Shawn had cornflakes, which I thought he had ordered because I had used up the magazine’s lunch allowance. I talked a lot, but I cannot remember what I said to him except that I liked the way Doris Troy sang, she sounds so fucked up. I said that to him. I didn’t know him at all then. I cannot remember what he said to me except that I could give writing something for the Talk of the Town a try. Months later, I attended an event; at this event, I made some notes in a small notebook George Trow had given to me; at home later, I wrote up my notes and added some impressions I had of the event. I thought Mr. Shawn would ask George to go over what I had put down, and put it into proper writing, but instead everything that I had written appeared in the magazine just the way I had written it. And when I saw that, I had a shock, because I realized then what my writing would be: the thoughts in my head, the way I thought of something, expressed in words. And that is how I came to feel that he is one of the sources of the person I have become.

—JAMAICA KINCAID

“Listening to jazz,” William Shawn once wrote, “has been one of the great pleasures of my life.” But playing his special Fats Waller-style piano was an even greater pleasure. In the late fifties, he presided over occasional musical evenings in his apartment, on the Upper East Side. I lived nearby, and, when summoned, wheeled my drums over in a baby carriage. He always opened the front door and, at the sight of the loaded carriage, shook his head in disbelief and laughed—but it wasn’t a laugh laugh. As was his way, he simply made a quick laughing sound and smiled without showing any teeth. After a buffet supper, the band assembled and took off. It generally included Shawn at his beautiful Steinway grand, Bruce Bliven on clarinet, three or four children (Wallace and Allen Shawn, Jay and Richard Hamburger) on violin, recorder, clarinet, and triangle, and me. The music was untrammelled. Sometimes the ensembles coalesced and sounded like Dixieland, and sometimes cacophony took over. The solos, often free of key, harmony, and melody, were piping and brave. All the while, Shawn sat behind his grand, jacket off, back to the wall, and played, his left hand pumping out Waller oompahs and his right hand doing some fancy fretwork. He watched his hands a lot, but when a child soloed he’d look up, his face glistening and pleased. Around nine-thirty, the children disappeared, and the session ended. The music, intense and very private, freed Shawn; he called me by my first name during those evenings and Mr. Balliett the rest of the forty-odd years we knew each other.

—WHITNEY BALLIETT

Mr. Shawn was open to and thrilled by people of talent, from the youngest to the oldest of them. He knew how to find the best story, the best writer, the right structure, the right sentence, the right word. I sometimes wondered how these overwhelming powers came to be vested in a man who was genuinely meek, in the Biblical sense, and was vulnerable and selfless. For me, his nature was expressed in the way I would see him pause on the street to make way for a baby carriage and then bow slightly and tip his hat to the baby.

When Mr. Shawn was removed by The New Yorker’s then fairly new owner, he was hurt, and hurt badly. But, in his usual reasonable manner, he seemed to be trying to understand the owner’s action. As time went on, he would say he was trying not to feel bitter. “Bitterness serves no purpose, and it corrodes the soul,” he would often say. Once, he gave me a sheet of paper on which he had just typed a few sentences. I read the following: “I have never experienced or even permitted myself to contemplate a vindictive action. I would rather carry around pain or disappointment or even the residue of bitterness for the balance of my life than to entertain a moment’s vengeful thought. . . . Little bitterness remains, but that little is far too much for me. The truth is I cannot bear it. If I cannot love my enemies, I cannot breathe.”

Over the past five years or so, Mr. Shawn worked in an office given to him by Lorne Michaels, the creator and executive producer of “Saturday Night Live.” The office was at Broadway Video, Michaels’s production and postproduction company, in the Brill Building. Day after day, Mr. Shawn went to this pleasant, buzzing place, and sat at Michaels’s desk, surrounded by artifacts of television and the entertainment business. He would bring all his papers with him in a fat brown leather briefcase, and would take them home at night, leaving no trace of his presence on the desk or in the typewriter. Among other things, he worked on writing fiction. His sentences, he would tell me, flowed easily and smoothly, and he experienced what other writers experience: his fingers would take over, and the writing would come as though from someone else. But, he said, sounding disappointed, he was not writing what he really wanted to write, and he was determined not to have it published. Finally, he seemed to find what he really wanted, and he started writing with hope and enthusiasm. But the physical stresses and strains of his life were by then piling up on him and soon stopped him from going on.

Four days before Mr. Shawn died, my twenty-six-year-old son, Erik, and I had a bite with him at Madison Avenue’s E.A.T. Café. (As far back as I can remember, Mr. Shawn loved sitting around in a nice café.) A paperback publisher had just sent me a paragraph that had been prepared for the cover of a book. I handed the paragraph to Mr. Shawn and asked him if he would check it. He took out the mechanical pencil he always carried in his inside jacket pocket, and quickly read the paragraph. Then, hesitantly, he asked if it would be all right to make a change. I told him I would be grateful for it. With his pencil, he made his characteristically neat proofreading marks on a sentence that said the book “remains as fresh and unique as ever.” He changed it to read “remains unique and as fresh as ever.” “There are no degrees of uniqueness,” Mr. Shawn said politely.

He was the one to know that. He embodied the meaning of the word. Later, I looked up, in the Concise Oxford Dictionary, the definition of “unique”: “a. of which there is only one, unequalled, having no like or equal or parallel.”

—LILLIAN Ross

In his youth, Shawn published a casual in the magazine which he later came to wish had been rejected. It appeared in 1936 and was signed only with his initials—W.S., not the most inconspicuous initials in the annals of English literature—and he took comfort in that partial concealment of his identity. The casual was an amusingly worked-out account of the sudden total destruction of New York City by a stray meteor. After the detonation of the first atomic bomb, Shawn felt that the topic could no longer be dealt with playfully and perhaps ought never to have been dealt with playfully. But playful his imagination was, whether or not he employed it in writing. I recall having lunch with Shawn one day—the usual gruel—in the course of which he developed a theory of conduct that was a merry mingling of mock science and mock philosophy. As time passes, what is the most appropriate way for us to live? Shawn proposed that we should take the number of years that in statistical terms could be thought to remain to us and then seek out a species of animal for which that number is the normal life span. We would then conduct ourselves for that number of years in approximately the same fashion that this animal does. If we have a life expectancy of fourteen years, then we should pattern ourselves after a kangaroo; if twenty-five years, then a giraffe; and so on. Shawn gave a name to this impromptu theory of his: he called it Temporarianism. As he got up from his meagre repast, he shook his head and exclaimed, “Think of it! To go down in history as the father of Temporarianism!”

—BRENDAN GILL

Some years ago, a writer who had just emerged from his first meeting with William Shawn blurted out, “He listens!” This was said in a tone of voice the writer might have used to say something like “He conducted the entire meeting while standing on his hands!” The more I thought about it, the more I came to believe that the astonishment was justified.

When a writer was in Shawn’s office, sitting on a couch otherwise occupied by piles of manuscripts, the door was closed. The phone almost never rang; when it did, Shawn took care of the call in a few seconds, and then apologized at greater length than that for the distraction. He focussed completely on the person sitting on the couch. While he listened to, say, the reasons a writer thought some subject was worth a story, he sometimes shook his head in wonderment or murmured “Really!” When he responded, it was clear that he had absorbed everything said—every fact, every allusion, every nuance. Shawn was that rare bird an inspirational listener. For thirty-five years, writers emerged from his office buoyed by the belief that at least one other human being in the world understood precisely what they were trying to get at.

I think his reputation for reclusiveness played a role in his gifts as a receiver of information: a writer who was researching a piece for The New Yorker had the feeling of gathering information for some terrifically intelligent, inexhaustibly curious uncle who happened to be a shut-in. Also, the writer didn’t have to worry about being second-guessed by somebody at a dinner party who had third-hand information and a confident manner. Shawn wouldn’t have been at the dinner party. (It is not true, by the way, that Shawn absolutely never went to parties. It would have been discourteous to ignore, say, a major gathering honoring New Yorker artists. On such occasions, he would arrive precisely on time, pay his respects to the guest of honor, who was probably the only other person in the room except the bartender, and flee. A writer who had encountered less midtown traffic than he expected on the way to some New Yorker event once said, “We got there so early we nearly saw Shawn.”)

He read every word that went into the magazine, and sent along annotated galleys of each piece to the editor handling it. He handled some pieces himself—including a few of mine, when I first arrived at The New Yorker. He would sit behind his desk, and I would sit on the couch. “On top of Galley 3,” he’d say, and as he read the sentence to me I’d realize that it was one of those sentences I’d handed in as imperfect beasts in the secret hope that they might get lost in the herd. What I found remarkable is not that he invariably put his finger on the flawed sentence but that as he read I often understood how to fix it.

It was characteristic of the way Shawn operated that he somehow led me to make the fix. His approach to editing involved what amounted to a conscious denial of ego—a characteristic so startling in the writing trade that it was, ironically, one of the bases of his fame.

—CALVIN TRILLIN

Certainly everything about him was touched with irony. He published some of the most sensitive prose the republic of letters has ever produced, but it was wedged in among some of the glossiest advertisements the world has ever seen. He was simple, natural, direct, and accessible, but the writers and artists he gathered around him tended to be temperamental, quirky, and complicated. He was aware of everybody’s foibles, but, like the father of a big family, he had complete charity: his affection for his writers and artists knew no bounds. He carried the weight of the world on his shoulders, and read newspapers avidly, because he knew that The New Yorker was a journalistic enterprise as well as a literary one. But he always appeared relaxed and laughed easily. For thirty-five years, he selected from a mountain of manuscripts everything that went into the magazine, and read proofs of each piece, often several times, before it was published. But as a person he never gave the impression of someone under pressure or in a hurry. A man who should have had a credit line on every piece in the magazine sought no credit from anybody.

—VED MEHTA

I hardly got to know Mr. Shawn in the brief time we coincided at the magazine, but as I tried to learn his job, and to understand how he had done it, I began to infer who and what he was. There were contradictions. The extraordinary mechanism he had developed for putting out issue after issue of the magazine so smoothly was the achievement of a mind devoted to order and process, yet it was clear that Shawn also relied on intuition and flair—his own and his writers’. The editorial staff he had created was brilliant and reliable, and he depended on it, yet it seemed to worry him that his colleagues’ very abilities might in some way muffle the direct connection between him and his writers. He was unrelenting in his insistence that everything in the magazine be accurate, clear, and, above all, judicious, yet he published work of great feeling and daring, and work that took large risks. His manner was unremittingly polite, even gentle, yet it was obvious that he was forceful and determined, and—always—in complete control.

There was, however, no contradiction in his devotion to the magazine. The New Yorker was for him a calling and a trust; a civilization, even—perhaps the last civilization. Many of our readers agreed with him about this, and, indeed, what ultimately moved me most about Mr. Shawn had to do with the faith that this famously private and fastidious editor had in his large public, and the reciprocal faith the public had in his magazine. Perhaps his most significant contribution to journalism lay in the triumph of his passionate and uncynical view of what a publication and its readers can mean to each other—a view unique in our time.

—ROBERT GOTTLIEB

Every encounter with William Shawn was a somewhat mystifyingly intense experience. You left his presence as you leave a play or a film that has taken you out of your own life and plunged you into a world that is more vivid, coherent, and interesting than the real world. Shawn was a great teacher, and the lesson he taught—the lesson every great teacher teaches—was the lesson of himself. He was the model and emblem of the uncorrupted intellect. T. S. Eliot’s famous description of Henry James—“He had a mind so fine that no idea could violate it”—could be a description of William Shawn. He never said anything that wasn’t profoundly intelligent and utterly intelligible. We, his students, without ever presuming to imitate him, tried to be like him in our work. We sought to eliminate from our writing the pretentiousness, intellectual shallowness, moral murkiness, and aesthetic limpness that come naturally to the pen. He was our beacon in a treacherous terrain. The thought of him ultimately reading what we had written both slowed us down and gave us courage to continue. The slowing down was the important thing. Shawn knew—and we knew he knew—that writing is a process that can’t be hurried, and that each piece has its natural, sometimes preposterously long term. He taught us to be patient, and to trust our material. He had the gaiety and the playfulness that all deeply serious people have. He was an enchanting person and an Enchanter. He was our Mr. Chips and our Prospero. We have missed him and we will always miss him.

—JANET MALCOLM

When someone dies, it is customary to pay tribute to his achievements and his better qualities. In the case of Mr. Shawn, there is so much—too much—to say about these. One would have to describe how he broadened and deepened the interests of the magazine until it became unique in the entire history of magazines; how, as managing editor and then as editor, he invented and thereafter supervised a radically original and bounteously successful administrative structure for the production of journalistic and literary work; how, swimming against the tide of the times, he pioneered, and persevered in, several deeply unfashionable editorial policies, such as resistance to public relations in all its forms; how, gauging the flow of that same tide, he saw the shape of things to come before they came, as if his mind dwelled in the anteroom of history, where events were taking shape and getting ready to be born; how he sent writers out to report on those events as they were occurring, years before any other editor did so; how, as an editor of writing, he seemed to change almost nothing, and yet somehow all was changed; how, while framing the broad policies of the magazine, he immersed himself in its details, with the result that in the end the policies were in fact nothing but the sum of the details, not something imposed from above; how, by virtue of a deep-rooted humility, he managed to place his prodigious mind wholly at the service of other minds, including, above all, the minds of New Yorker writers, so that in his presence you felt that you were wittier, more interesting, finer—a better person over all—than you had thought a moment before. And one would have to describe his incomparable judgment, which included what Hannah Arendt once called his “moral perfect pitch”; his courtesy, which was the outward expression of his respect for other people (Mr. Shawn was a kind of one-man civilization, and his manners were its singular manners); his fabled responsiveness, to writing, to events, and, above all, to people; and his sheer stamina, which, in its unobtrusive way, resembled nothing so much as that of some great general—a Napoleon or a Kutuzov.

All these achievements and qualities and many more would have to be described to take the measure of our loss, and they should be, because there is so much to learn from his life about how to run a magazine, how to think about the world and live in it, and how to be a human being. It’s disturbing to those who knew him to realize that the world now goes its way unwatched by him. But at this moment, when the shock and heartache of his death are fresh, what I want above all to remember are certain other things. I want to remember the delicacy and gentleness—almost a kind of tenderness—with which he treated everyone in his presence: family, friends, and colleagues. His feeling for the people he worked with was personal. One reason, I suspect, that he shunned publicity and found it distasteful to hold meetings with more than a few people (and most of the time there was just one other person) is that he had no “professional” self to call upon for such occasions. For him, everything was personal. His devotion to his colleagues was unqualified. This devotion was instantly visible in his glance—shy but dead level—whenever, rosy-cheeked and blue-suited, he appeared in one’s doorway. It was a glance so filled with affectionate, alert, and intelligent attention that you could dwell in it, and a few generations of people who worked at The New Yorker did dwell in it. The attention did not falter when, as so often had to be the case, it fell on someone who was unhappy or in anguish. Part of his responsiveness was his immediate, great-hearted reaction to people’s suffering. He received news of someone’s divorce, illness, bereavement, or other sorrow as if it were a physical blow. He would slump back in his chair, his shoulders would fall, his face would lose color, and he would emit an “Oh, no!” that was near a sob. Because his life consisted in large measure of watching over several hundred lives, the blows came often. This unlimited fellow-feeling, this love, was of a piece with his genius as an editor, and, perhaps, was at the heart of it.

He had the highest expectations and the highest standards of anyone I have ever met. Such a person might have been forbidding. But he was sweet, patient, forbearing, steadfast, and kind. To be in his company was a delight, a joy. Along with everything else, he was a magical man. In twenty years of working with him, every time I heard his distinctive, soft, sliding footfall in the corridor, my heart lifted in happiness.

—JONATHAN SCHELL

On February 12, 1987, the day before he left The New Yorker, William Shawn wrote this letter to the staff:

Dear colleagues, dear friends:

My feelings at this perplexed moment are too strong for farewells. I will miss you terribly, but I can be grateful to have had your companionship for part of my journey through the years. Whatever our individual roles at The New Yorker, whether on the eighteenth, nineteenth, or twentieth floor, we have built something quite wonderful together. Love has been the controlling emotion, and love is the essential word. We have done our work with honesty and love. The New Yorker, as a reader once said, has been the gentlest of magazines. Perhaps it has also been the greatest, but that matters far less. What matters most is that you and I, working together, taking strength from the inspiration that our first editor, Harold Ross, gave us, have tried constantly to find and say what is true. I must speak of love once more. I love all of you, and will love you as long as I live.

WILLIAM SHAWN

Published in the print edition of the December 28, 1992 & January 4, 1993, issue.
